trans-unit.source: Creating the GIT repos
trans-unit.target: Creating the GIT repos

trans-unit.source: It is the content owner's responsibility to create the GIT repos and provide the right permissions to the users to access them.
trans-unit.target: It is the content owner's responsibility to create the GIT repos and provide the right permissions to the users to access them.

trans-unit.source: A GIT repo is either GitHub or Visual Studio Online.
trans-unit.target: A GIT repo is either GitHub or Visual Studio Online.

trans-unit.source: If you are not familiar with GitHub, check out a summary of <linkText>GitHub terminology</linkText><title></title> used in this documentation as well as the <linkText>GitHub tutorials</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: If you are not familiar with GitHub, check out a summary of <linkText>GitHub terminology</linkText><title></title> used in this documentation as well as the <linkText>GitHub tutorials</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: For GitHub repository setup, follow the <linkText>GitHub tutorials</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For GitHub repository setup, follow the <linkText>GitHub tutorials</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For Visual Studio Online see (TBD).
trans-unit.target: For Visual Studio Online see (TBD).

trans-unit.source: 1. Create the repo
trans-unit.target: 1. Create the repo

trans-unit.source: The first step is to create a GIT repository.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to create a GIT repository.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you add a readme.md file to the repo.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you add a readme.md file to the repo.

trans-unit.source: You will need this file to tell your users how to contribute to the repo.
trans-unit.target: You will need this file to tell your users how to contribute to the repo.

trans-unit.source: Decide whether the repo is going to be public or private.
trans-unit.target: Decide whether the repo is going to be public or private.

trans-unit.source: 1.1 GitHub Private vs. public repo
trans-unit.target: 1.1 GitHub Private vs. public repo

trans-unit.source: If you do not want/need external contributions (i.e. external to Microsoft), you would need create a private repo.
trans-unit.target: If you do not want/need external contributions (i.e. external to Microsoft), you would need create a private repo.

trans-unit.source: If you want/need external contributions (i.e. external to Microsoft), then you would need to create two repos: one public and one private.
trans-unit.target: If you want/need external contributions (i.e. external to Microsoft), then you would need to create two repos: one public and one private.

trans-unit.source: The private repo will contain the under development content, that is, the content that your customers cannot see.
trans-unit.target: The private repo will contain the under development content, that is, the content that your customers cannot see.

trans-unit.source: The public repo will contain the content that is widely available, which your customers can contribute to.
trans-unit.target: The public repo will contain the content that is widely available, which your customers can contribute to.

trans-unit.source: Note, even if you have not published you content live, anything in the public repo will be visible to external users.
trans-unit.target: Note, even if you have not published you content live, anything in the public repo will be visible to external users.

trans-unit.source: You can also create a private fork out of your private repo.
trans-unit.target: You can also create a private fork out of your private repo.

trans-unit.source: This <linkText>article</linkText><title></title> shows you how.
trans-unit.target: This <linkText>article</linkText><title></title> shows you how.

trans-unit.source: If you create both kinds of repo (private and public), you need to manually synchronize your private repo to your public repo when you are ready to make the content available to your customers.
trans-unit.target: If you create both kinds of repo (private and public), you need to manually synchronize your private repo to your public repo when you are ready to make the content available to your customers.

trans-unit.source: Here is a recommendation:
trans-unit.target: Here is a recommendation:

trans-unit.source: Pull the changes made in the public repo into a local branch of the private repo.
trans-unit.target: Pull the changes made in the public repo into a local branch of the private repo.

trans-unit.source: Fix any merge conflicts and submit a pull request to the (master)(GitHub-terminology.md) branch in the private repo.
trans-unit.target: Fix any merge conflicts and submit a pull request to the (master)(GitHub-terminology.md) branch in the private repo.

trans-unit.source: Once the pull request passes validation, merge it to the master branch in the private repo.
trans-unit.target: Once the pull request passes validation, merge it to the master branch in the private repo.

trans-unit.source: Create a pull request to add the info from the private repo into the public repo.
trans-unit.target: Create a pull request to add the info from the private repo into the public repo.

trans-unit.source: Revolve any conficts.
trans-unit.target: Revolve any conficts.

trans-unit.source: Once the two repos have synced, you can publish the content you merged in from the public repo.
trans-unit.target: Once the two repos have synced, you can publish the content you merged in from the public repo.

trans-unit.source: As Open Publishing offers local preview, you can always pull changes from the public repo to your private repo to have a full view of your content.
trans-unit.target: As Open Publishing offers local preview, you can always pull changes from the public repo to your private repo to have a full view of your content.

trans-unit.source: The following two images show a graphical view of the recommended workflow.
trans-unit.target: The following two images show a graphical view of the recommended workflow.

trans-unit.source: Note this is only added here for your reference.
trans-unit.target: Note this is only added here for your reference.

trans-unit.target: 1.1.1 Internal contributions only workflow

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Internal created content</linkText>

trans-unit.target: 1.1.2 External contributions workflow

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Internal created content</linkText>

trans-unit.source: 2. Creating your repo in the Microsoft GitHub Organization
trans-unit.target: 2. Creating your repo in the Microsoft GitHub Organization

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you create the repo in the Microsoft GibHub Organization.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you create the repo in the Microsoft GibHub Organization.

trans-unit.source: That way, you can benefit of all the advantages the organizaiton provides, including enabling Contributaion License Agreement (CLA) automation.
trans-unit.target: That way, you can benefit of all the advantages the organizaiton provides, including enabling Contributaion License Agreement (CLA) automation.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to Create a Repo in the Microsoft GitHub Organization</linkText><title></title> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to Create a Repo in the Microsoft GitHub Organization</linkText><title></title> for details.

trans-unit.source: When creating the organization, choose:
trans-unit.target: When creating the organization, choose:

trans-unit.source: MIT license
trans-unit.target: MIT license

trans-unit.source: Choose Sample code exception unless your repo will also have samples.
trans-unit.target: Choose Sample code exception unless your repo will also have samples.

trans-unit.source: 3. Setting up permissions to the GIT repo
trans-unit.target: 3. Setting up permissions to the GIT repo

trans-unit.source: For permission to access the content repo, the content owner is responsible for leveraging GITHUB permission system.
trans-unit.target: For permission to access the content repo, the content owner is responsible for leveraging GITHUB permission system.

trans-unit.source: The owner will need to give the appropriate users read or write permission to the repo (private or public).
trans-unit.target: The owner will need to give the appropriate users read or write permission to the repo (private or public).

trans-unit.source: Our recommendation is you create an org and host the repo under that org, then add users to that org to give them write permission.
trans-unit.target: Our recommendation is you create an org and host the repo under that org, then add users to that org to give them write permission.

trans-unit.source: Users are always able to publish by pushing a change to a branch, as long as they have the push permission to the repo.
trans-unit.target: Users are always able to publish by pushing a change to a branch, as long as they have the push permission to the repo.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about repo permissions in GitHub, please see the (Repository permission levels for an organization page)[https://help.github.com/articles/repository-permission-levels-for-an-organization/].
trans-unit.target: To learn more about repo permissions in GitHub, please see the (Repository permission levels for an organization page)[https://help.github.com/articles/repository-permission-levels-for-an-organization/].

trans-unit.source: 4. Creating and setting up localized repos
trans-unit.target: 4. Creating and setting up localized repos

trans-unit.source: The localized content will live in a separated repo, connected to the English one.
trans-unit.target: The localized content will live in a separated repo, connected to the English one.

trans-unit.source: For that, you need to modify the config file .localization-config.This file contains the definition of the localized repos.
trans-unit.target: For that, you need to modify the config file .localization-config.This file contains the definition of the localized repos.

trans-unit.source: locales - add the locales you would like to localize in the form of locale-culture set.
trans-unit.target: locales - add the locales you would like to localize in the form of locale-culture set.

trans-unit.source: E.g. "ja-jp", "de-de",...
trans-unit.target: E.g. "ja-jp", "de-de",...

trans-unit.source: files - List all the folders and file types to localize, include the docset name plus "**" to include all the folders underneath, and then mask the file types.
trans-unit.target: files - List all the folders and file types to localize, include the docset name plus "**" to include all the folders underneath, and then mask the file types.

trans-unit.source: E.g. "virtualization/*/.md" includes all the Markdown files under the docset, including all the subfolders.
trans-unit.target: E.g. "virtualization/*/.md" includes all the Markdown files under the docset, including all the subfolders.

trans-unit.source: includeDependencies
trans-unit.target: includeDependencies

trans-unit.source: Set to true to include in the handoffs the topic dependencies (includes).
trans-unit.target: Set to true to include in the handoffs the topic dependencies (includes).

trans-unit.source: Set to false to only include the Markdown files.
trans-unit.target: Set to false to only include the Markdown files.

trans-unit.source: autoPush
trans-unit.target: autoPush

trans-unit.source: Set to true to automatically check-in the hand back files into the localized repo.
trans-unit.target: Set to true to automatically check-in the hand back files into the localized repo.

trans-unit.source: Set to false to create a pull request for the hand back so an admin can approve.
trans-unit.target: Set to false to create a pull request for the hand back so an admin can approve.

trans-unit.source: Once this file has been committed, if there is a new language added under locales, the localized repo will be created automatically after the English branches publish.
trans-unit.target: Once this file has been committed, if there is a new language added under locales, the localized repo will be created automatically after the English branches publish.

trans-unit.source: 5. Next: Configure your repo
trans-unit.target: 5. Next: Configure your repo

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure your repo</linkText><title></title>
